elements.content: On the basis of the designed bifunctional 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­terephthalic acid (H2BTA) ligand, a series of three-dimensional lanthanide coordination polymers, namely, [La2(BTA)1.5­(ox)1.5­(H2O)3] n (1), [Nd­(BTA)­(ox)0.5­(H2O)] n (2), {[Ln­(HBTA)­(ox)­(H2O)]­·xH2O} n (Ln = Pr for 3 (x = 0), Sm for 4 (x = 0), Dy for 5 (x = 1.5), and Eu for 6 (x = 1)), and [Ln­(BTA)­(SO4)0.5­(H2O)] n (Ln = Eu for 7, and Tb for 8) were obtained with the help of oxalate or sulfate ions. On the basis of the binuclear La2 secondary building unit (SBUs), the framework of 1 displays an unprecedented (3,3,4,9)-connected net with the point symbol of (411.55.614.75.8)2­(42.5)2(43)2­(44.62). While in complex 2, the binuclear Nd2 SBUs are connected by the BTA2– ligands to generate an interestingly (4,10)-connected (412.516.612.75)­(46)2 net. Complexes 3–6 are isomorphism and show a 2-fold interpenetrated 4-connected (66)-dia net. Complexes 7 and 8 are isomorphism and show a novel (4,5)-connected (44.62)­(44.66) net. Photoluminescence investigations show that 2 is a good near-infrared luminescent material, and 4 is a rarely reported single component white light emitting material. Complexes 6 and 7 show typically red emission, while complex 8 shows typically green emission, which can be used as a red or green emitting phosphor. Moreover, the luminescent lifetimes and quantum yields of the titled complexes were investigated. The magnetic susceptibility data of 2 indicated there are antiferromagnetic interactions between the NdIII ions.

While in complex 2, the binuclear Nd2 SBUs are connected by the BTA2- ligands to generate an interestingly (4,10)-connected (412.516.612.75)(46)2 net. elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The lanthanide coordination polymers (LnCPs) have attracted upsurging research interest for their attractive structures as well as gigantic prospective applications in the field of gas storage, electronic device, molecular switch, catalysis, nonlinear optics, and biological activity. Such materials are generally constructed from the organic linkers and Ln ions, which are often affected by a myriad of influence factors.

elements.content: The design and selection of organic linkers proved to be an efficiently routine in the assembly of functional LnCPs. Notably, the polycarboxylates and nitrogen heterocyclic compounds are two most selective candidates in building high-dimensional architectures for their strong coordination abilities and versatile bridging fashion. However, bifunctional organic ligands, which contain both polycarboxylate and imidazole ring, were rarely reported, comparatively.

elements.content: As we all known, applications are determined by properties which are essentially derived from their microstructure. The 4f electron configurations of the LnIII ions endow the LnCPs unique luminescence with high luminescence quantum yield, and sharp, narrow, and well-separated emission bands. Thus, the LnCPs can generate high purity visible and near-infrared light-emitting emission, which makes it possible to act as luminescent materials, highlighted by some articles recently. The introduction of organic linkers allows the LnCPs tunable platforms to generate luminescence with the model of the metal–ligand or ligand–metal charge transfers.

The photoluminescence investigations shows that the 2 is a good near-infrared luminescent material, and 4 is a rarely reported single component white light emitting material. Complexes 6 and 7 show typically red emission, while complex 8 shows typically green emission, which can be used as a red or green emitting phosphor.

elements.content: The ligand of 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­terephthalic acid was synthesized with the help of Jinan Henghua Sci. & Tec. Co. Ltd.. All other starting reagents were commercially obtained without further purification. IR spectra were collected on a Nicolet 740 FTIR spectrometer from KBr pellets. Elemental analyses (EA) of C, N, and H were conducted on the CE instruments EA 1110 elemental analyzer. TG curves were carried out on a SDT Q600 instrument from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a N2 flow. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses for titled complexes were obtained on a Panalytical X-Pert pro diffractometer (Cu–Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å). Solid state emission spectra were detected on an F-4600 FL spectrophotometer. And the temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility data was measured on a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS XL-7 instruments.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

The ligand of 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)terephthalic acid was synthesized with the help of Jinan Henghua Sci. & Tec. Co. Ltd.. All other starting reagents were commercially obtained without further purification. IR spectra were collected on a Nicolet 740 FTIR spectrometer from KBr pellets. Elemental analyses (EA) of C, N, and H were conducted on the CE instruments EA 1110 elemental analyzer. TG curves were carried out on a SDT Q600 instrument from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a N2 flow. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses for titled complexes were obtained on a Panalytical X-Pert pro diffractometer (Cu-Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å). Solid state emission spectra were detected on an F-4600 FL spectrophotometer. And the temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility data was measured on a Quantum Design SQUID MPMS XL-7 instruments.

elements.content: p-Xylene (10.6 g, 0.1 mol), I2 (0.1 g), and 30% H2O2 (10 mL) were dissolved in 1000 mL of CH2Cl2 and were cooled below 5 °C in an icewater bath. Br2 (11.3 mL, 0.22 mol) was dropped in the cooled solution and stirred for 24 h. Then saturated sodium hyposulfite solution was added to remove redundant Br2 and I2. The separated organic solution was reduced to 200 mL by evaporation. Colorless crystalline 2,5-dibromo-p-xylene (II) was obtained with a yield of 95%. Anal. (%) calcd. for C8H8Br2: C, 36.40; H, 3.05. Found: C, 36.34; H, 2.99.
elements.clean_text:
Design of 1,4-Bis(imidazol-1-yl)terephthalic Acid (H2BTA)

Synthesis of 2,5-Dibromo-p-xylene (II)

 p-Xylene (10.6 g, 0.1 mol), I2 (0.1 g), and 30% H2O2 (10 mL) were dissolved in 1000 mL of CH2Cl2 and were cooled below 5 °C in an icewater bath. Br2 (11.3 mL, 0.22 mol) was dropped in the cooled solution and stirred for 24 h. Then saturated sodium hyposulfite solution was added to remove redundant Br2 and I2. The separated organic solution was reduced to 200 mL by evaporation. Colorless crystalline 2,5-dibromo-p-xylene (II) was obtained with a yield of 95%. Anal. (%) calcd. for C8H8Br2: C, 36.40; H, 3.05. Found: C, 36.34; H, 2.99.

elements.content: The mixture of 2,5-dibromo-p-xylene (II) (0.1 mol, 26.2 g) and 100 mL of tert-butanol in 1000 mL of H2O was refluxed, and then potassium permanganate (76 g, 0.48 mol) was slowly added. After the mixture was refluxed a further 4 h, ethanol was added to remove redundant potassium permanganate. The filtrated solution was acidified with the concentrated HCl, and then a white predicate was obtained, which was recrystallized with DMF. The yield is 65%. Anal. (%) calcd. for C8H4Br2O4: C, 29.66; H, 1.24. Found: C, 29.47; H, 1.11.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 2,5-Dibromoterephthalic Acid (III)

The mixture of 2,5-dibromo-p-xylene (II) (0.1 mol, 26.2 g) and 100 mL of tert-butanol in 1000 mL of H2O was refluxed, and then potassium permanganate (76 g, 0.48 mol) was slowly added. After the mixture was refluxed a further 4 h, ethanol was added to remove redundant potassium permanganate. The filtrated solution was acidified with the concentrated HCl, and then a white predicate was obtained, which was recrystallized with DMF. The yield is 65%. Anal. (%) calcd. for C8H4Br2O4: C, 29.66; H, 1.24. Found: C, 29.47; H, 1.11.

elements.content: 2,5-Dibromoterephthalic acid (0.05 mol, 16.0 g) was suspended in 500 mL of ethanol with 20 mL of H2SO4 and was refluxed overnight, and then the mixture was poured into 1000 mL of icewater. The solution was neutralized with ammonium water and extracted with CH2Cl2 three times. Obtained organic solution was concentrated, and a colorless crystalline product was collected with 90% yield. Anal. (%) calcd. for C12H12Br2O4: C, 37.93; H, 3.18. Found: C, 37.72; H, 3.08.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ethyl 2,5-Dibromoterephthalate (IV)

2,5-Dibromoterephthalic acid (0.05 mol, 16.0 g) was suspended in 500 mL of ethanol with 20 mL of H2SO4 and was refluxed overnight, and then the mixture was poured into 1000 mL of icewater. The solution was neutralized with ammonium water and extracted with CH2Cl2 three times. Obtained organic solution was concentrated, and a colorless crystalline product was collected with 90% yield. Anal. (%) calcd. for C12H12Br2O4: C, 37.93; H, 3.18. Found: C, 37.72; H, 3.08.

elements.content: The mixture of IV (0.01 mol, 3.8 g), imidazole (0.1 mol, 6.8 g), CuSO4 (0.5 g), and K2CO3 (0.1 mol, 13.8 g) was refluxed for 4 h and was dissolved in 500 mL of EtOH. The solution was decoloured with activated carbon and concentrated to 100 mL. Crude product was obtained and recrystallized with mixed solvent of ethyl acetate and DMF. Anal. (%) calcd. for C18H18N4O4: C, 61.01; H, 5.12; N, 15.81. Found: C, 60.85; H, 5.03; N, 15.65.

The mixture of IV (0.01 mol, 3.8 g), imidazole (0.1 mol, 6.8 g), CuSO4 (0.5 g), and K2CO3 (0.1 mol, 13.8 g) was refluxed for 4 h and was dissolved in 500 mL of EtOH. The solution was decoloured with activated carbon and concentrated to 100 mL. Crude product was obtained and recrystallized with mixed solvent of ethyl acetate and DMF. Anal. (%) calcd. for C18H18N4O4: C, 61.01; H, 5.12; N, 15.81. Found: C, 60.85; H, 5.03; N, 15.65.

elements.content: The mixture of V (0.01 mol, 3.5 g) and 20 mL of concentrated HCl in 100 mL of H2O was refluxed overnight and filtrated. The obtained precipitate was recrystallized DMF to obtain a white powder. EI-MS: m/z [M – H]−, 297.07 (calcd for C14H10N4O4, 298.07). Anal. (%) calcd. for C14H10N4O4: C, 56.38; H, 3.38; N, 18.78. Found: C, 56.22; H, 3.16; N, 18.60.

elements.content: The single-crystal data of titled LnCPs of 1–8 were collected on a Siemens SMART diffractometer with graphite-monochromatized Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Empirical absorption corrections and Lorentz polarization were applied. Those structures were resolved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the package of SHELXTL-97. Detailed crystallographic data and structural refinements of those complexes are gathered in Table S1, and the Ln-N/O bond distances and selected angles around the Ln ions are given in Table S2. Further information about the data can be obtained by visiting the Web site of http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/ on quoting the depository number CCDC-1471606 for 1, 1471607 for 2, 1471608 for 3, 1471609 for 4, 1471610 for 5, 1471611 for 6, 1471612 for 7, and 1471613 for 8, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The single-crystal data of titled LnCPs of 1-8 were collected on a Siemens SMART diffractometer with graphite-monochromatized Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Empirical absorption corrections and Lorentz polarization were applied. Those structures were resolved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 by using the package of SHELXTL-97. Detailed crystallographic data and structural refinements of those complexes are gathered in Table S1, and the Ln-N/O bond distances and selected angles around the Ln ions are given in Table S2. Further information about the data can be obtained by visiting the Web site of http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/ on quoting the depository number CCDC-1471606 for 1, 1471607 for 2, 1471608 for 3, 1471609 for 4, 1471610 for 5, 1471611 for 6, 1471612 for 7, and 1471613 for 8, respectively.

elements.content: Complexes 1–8 were obtained from the reaction of designed H2BTA and related lanthanide salts with the help of oxalate or sulfate ions under the solvothermal reactions. The titled complexes can be stable in the air and hold very poor solubility in the common solvents. The X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) analyses proved the titled complexes have a good phase purity (Figure S1), and the main vibrations in the IR spectra around 1510/1620 cm–1 of the carboxyl groups’ asymmetric/symmetric stretching vibrations are also in agreement with the crystal structures (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

General Synthesis and Characterization

Complexes 1-8 were obtained from the reaction of designed H2BTA and related lanthanide salts with the help of oxalate or sulfate ions under the solvothermal reactions. The titled complexes can be stable in the air and hold very poor solubility in the common solvents. The X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) analyses proved the titled complexes have a good phase purity (Figure S1), and the main vibrations in the IR spectra around 1510/1620 cm-1 of the carboxyl groups' asymmetric/symmetric stretching vibrations are also in agreement with the crystal structures (Figure S2).

elements.content: Complex 1 crystallized in triclinic space group P1̅, with two LaIII ions, one and a half of BTA2– ligands, one and a half of oxalate ions, and three coordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit (a). La1 located in a distorted [LaNO8] tricapped trigonal prismatic coordination geometry with the O2, O5, O3B, O4B, O10C, and N5D form a trigonal prism, and O6A, O7C, and O10E as capping atoms (b). La2 is nonacoordinated with one imidazole N atom (N4) from one BTA2– ligand, two carboxyl O atoms (O12, and O1E) from two other BTA2– ligands, three O atoms (O8, O9, and O8E) from two different ox2– ligands, and three coordinated water molecules, displaying a similar distorted [LaNO8] tricapped trigonal prismatic coordination geometry with the O9, O14, O15, O1E, O8E, and N4 forming a trigonal prism, and O8, O11 and O12 acting as capping atoms (c). Besides, the La–O bond distances span ranged from 2.432(1) Å to 2.736(8) Å, and the La–N bond lengths are 2.667(2) Å and 2.728(7) Å, respectively.

Structural Description of [La2(BTA)1.5(ox)1.5(H2O)3] n  (1)

Complex 1 crystallized in triclinic space group P1̅, with two LaIII ions, one and a half of BTA2- ligands, one and a half of oxalate ions, and three coordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit (a). La1 located in a distorted [LaNO8] tricapped trigonal prismatic coordination geometry with the O2, O5, O3B, O4B, O10C, and N5D form a trigonal prism, and O6A, O7C, and O10E as capping atoms (b). La2 is nonacoordinated with one imidazole N atom (N4) from one BTA2- ligand, two carboxyl O atoms (O12, and O1E) from two other BTA2- ligands, three O atoms (O8, O9, and O8E) from two different ox2- ligands, and three coordinated water molecules, displaying a similar distorted [LaNO8] tricapped trigonal prismatic coordination geometry with the O9, O14, O15, O1E, O8E, and N4 forming a trigonal prism, and O8, O11 and O12 acting as capping atoms (c). Besides, the La-O bond distances span ranged from 2.432(1) Å to 2.736(8) Å, and the La-N bond lengths are 2.667(2) Å and 2.728(7) Å, respectively.

elements.content: In the assembly of LnCPs, the oxalate was often selected as the secondary linker to construct high-connected architectures, which can be attributed to the strong coordination ability as well as various coordination modes. Besides, the oxalate and its related salt can be used as a buffer system to offer a stable reaction environment. It is interestingly to note that oxalate adopted two distinct modes when coordinating the LaIII ions in complex 1: one is the normal μ2-κ1:κ1:κ1:κ1 type (Type I), and the other is the first reported μ4-κ1:κ2:κ1:κ2 type (Type II), proven by the CSD survey by using the ConQuest version 1.3. The Type II typed oxalate linked with two La1 ions and two La2 ions alternately, leaving 1D [La2(ox)] n chains, which were further expanded into a 2D [La2(ox)3] n sheet by the Type I typed oxalate bridged the neighboring La2 ions (d).
elements.clean_text: In the assembly of LnCPs, the oxalate was often selected as the secondary linker to construct high-connected architectures, which can be attributed to the strong coordination ability as well as various coordination modes. Besides, the oxalate and its related salt can be used as a buffer system to offer a stable reaction environment. It is interestingly to note that oxalate adopted two distinct modes when coordinating the LaIII ions in complex 1: one is the normal μ2-κ1:κ1:κ1:κ1 type (Type I), and the other is the first reported μ4-κ1:κ2:κ1:κ2 type (Type II), proven by the CSD survey by using the ConQuest version 1.3. The Type II typed oxalate linked with two La1 ions and two La2 ions alternately, leaving 1D [La2(ox)] n  chains, which were further expanded into a 2D [La2(ox)3] n  sheet by the Type I typed oxalate bridged the neighboring La2 ions (d).

elements.content: In the formation of complex 1, the bifunctional H2BTA ligand completely deprotonated and adopted two different coordination modes when interacting with the LaIII ions. One kind of BTA2– ligand adopted the μ4-(η2)-κ1 N-(η1:η1) mode (Mode I, in , linked with four LaIII ions through the one imidazole N atom and the bridging μ2-η1:η1, and chelating η2 carboxyl groups). At the same time, the other BTA2– ligand adopted the μ4-(η1)-κ1 N-(η1)-κ1 N mode (Mode II), connected with four LaIII ions with two imidazole N atoms and two monodentate η1 carboxyl groups. Notably, the bridging μ2-η1:η1 carboxyl group bridged adjacent La1 and La2 ions, giving a binuclear La2 secondary building unit (SBU), with a La1···La2 distance of 5.194(3) Å. And in the assembly of complex 1, the imidazole rings can be rotated through the C–C bonds to satisfy the coordination preference of the LaIII ion, with the dihedral angles for δ, ε, and ζ of 52.22(6)°, 41.15(6)°, and 11.43(0)° for Mode I typed BTA2– ligand (), and 35.88(8)°, 35.88(8)°, and 0.00(0)° for Mode II, in which the δ, ε, and ζ corresponding to the dihedral angles between aromatic rings of A/B, B/C, and A/C, respectively. Two kinds of BTA2– linkers coordinated with the La2 SBUs, successfully constructed a 3D [La2(BTA)2] n network (e), which can be simplified to be a 3,4,5-connected (42.6)2(42.84)­(43.6.86)2-3,4,5T3 net (f and a). By sharing the La2 SBUs, the 3D [La2(BTA)2] n network incorporated with the 2D [La2(ox)3] n sheets, finally given a 3D architecture (g).

elements.content: Although under a similar reaction condition, when the La­(NO3)3 was replaced by the Nd­(NO3)3, a distinct 3D (4,10)-connected net was generated. 2 crystallized in monoclinic space group P21/n with the asymmetric unit comprising one NdIII ion, one BTA2– ligand, a half of oxalate ions, one coordinated water molecule (a). Each NdIII center is surrounded by two N atoms (N4F, N1G) from two BTA2– ligands, six O atoms from three other BTA2– ligands (O4, O5D, and O6E), one oxalate (O1, and O2A), and one water molecule (O3), leaving a [NdN2O6] bicapped trigonal prismatic geometry with the O2A, O4, O5D, O6E, N1G, and N4F form a trigonal prism, and O1 and O3 act as capping atoms (b). Besides, the Nd–O bond distances ranged from 2.427(2) Å to 2.576(4) Å, and the Nd–N bond lengths are 2.684(5) Å and 2.693(1) Å, respectively.

Structural Description of [Nd(BTA)(ox)0.5(H2O)] n  (2)

Although under a similar reaction condition, when the La(NO3)3 was replaced by the Nd(NO3)3, a distinct 3D (4,10)-connected net was generated. 2 crystallized in monoclinic space group P21/n with the asymmetric unit comprising one NdIII ion, one BTA2- ligand, a half of oxalate ions, one coordinated water molecule (a). Each NdIII center is surrounded by two N atoms (N4F, N1G) from two BTA2- ligands, six O atoms from three other BTA2- ligands (O4, O5D, and O6E), one oxalate (O1, and O2A), and one water molecule (O3), leaving a [NdN2O6] bicapped trigonal prismatic geometry with the O2A, O4, O5D, O6E, N1G, and N4F form a trigonal prism, and O1 and O3 act as capping atoms (b). Besides, the Nd-O bond distances ranged from 2.427(2) Å to 2.576(4) Å, and the Nd-N bond lengths are 2.684(5) Å and 2.693(1) Å, respectively.

elements.content: The BTA2– ligand adopted μ5-(η1)-κ1 N-(η1:η1)-κ1 N coordination mode (Mode III) in complex 2, with the dihedral angles of δ, ε, and ζ are 29.76(7)°, 49.90(2)°, and 78.45(2)°, respectively. Notably, the bridging μ2-η1:η1 carboxyl group bridged adjacent Nd ions, giving a binuclear Nd2 SBU, with the Nd···Nd distance is 5.746(9) Å. The oxalate ions bridged the neighboring Nd2 SBUs, successfully created an interestingly 1D chain with the oxalate separated adjacent Nd2 SBUs distance being 6.644(5) Å (c). And along the expanded direction of terephthalic acid, the Nd2 SBUs were bridged with the terephthalic acid units, forming a 1D ladder chain (d). Each μ5-BTA2– linker connected five NdIII ions by using two imidazole N atoms, one bridging μ2-η1:η1, and one monodentate η1 carboxyl groups, successfully constructed a 3D [Nd­(BTA)] n network (e), which can be defined as a 4,8-connected (412.612.84)­(46)2-flu net (f). Incorporating with the oxalate ions, the final 3D framework was constructed (g).

elements.content: Under the same condition, 2-fold interpenetrated 3D dia architectures were obtained when the Ln­(NO3)3 (Ln = Pr, Eu, Dy, and Sm) were introduced into the reaction. X-ray single-crystal analyses of complexes 3–6 show that they are isostructural, and the structure of complex 3 was selected as a representative herein. Complex 3 crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/c, and the asymmetric unit contains one PrIII ion, one HBTA– ligand, one oxalate ion, and one coordinated water molecule (a). Each PrIII ion is coordinated with nine oxygen atoms from two HBTA– ligands through chelating η2 carboxyl groups (O1, O2, O3D, and O4D), two oxalate ions (O5, O6, O8, and O9), and one water molecule (O7), to form a distorted [PrO9] tricapped trigonal prismatic coordination polyhedron with the O2, O3D, O5, O6, O8, and O9 form a trigonal prism, and O1, O7, and O4D act as capping atoms (b). And the Pr–O bond distances spanned from 2.467(6) Å to 2.623(5) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of [Ln(HBTA)(ox)(H2O)] n  (Ln = Pr for 3, Sm for 4, Dy for 5, and Eu for 6)

Under the same condition, 2-fold interpenetrated 3D dia architectures were obtained when the Ln(NO3)3 (Ln = Pr, Eu, Dy, and Sm) were introduced into the reaction. X-ray single-crystal analyses of complexes 3-6 show that they are isostructural, and the structure of complex 3 was selected as a representative herein. Complex 3 crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/c, and the asymmetric unit contains one PrIII ion, one HBTA- ligand, one oxalate ion, and one coordinated water molecule (a). Each PrIII ion is coordinated with nine oxygen atoms from two HBTA- ligands through chelating η2 carboxyl groups (O1, O2, O3D, and O4D), two oxalate ions (O5, O6, O8, and O9), and one water molecule (O7), to form a distorted [PrO9] tricapped trigonal prismatic coordination polyhedron with the O2, O3D, O5, O6, O8, and O9 form a trigonal prism, and O1, O7, and O4D act as capping atoms (b). And the Pr-O bond distances spanned from 2.467(6) Å to 2.623(5) Å.

elements.content: As a different form in the former complexes, the HBTA– ligand adopted μ2-(η2)-(η2) mode (Mode IV) in complex 3, linked two PrIII ions only through the chelating η2 carboxyl groups, and successfully generated a 1D zigzag [Pr­(HBTA)] n chain with the neighboring Pr···Pr distance of 11.597(6) Å. The dihedral angles of δ, ε, and ζ for HBTA– ligand are 48.74(7)°, 42.33(2)°, and 6.70(7)°, respectively, which indicates that the imidazole ring rotated through the C–C bonds when the carboxyl oxygen atoms coordinated with the metal centers to reduce the steric effect. Besides, the oxalate ions bridged the adjacent PrIII ions, and a 1D [Pr­(ox)] n polymeric chain emerged, with the ox2– separated Pr···Pr distances of 6.388(7) Å (Pr1···Pr1B), and 6.450(1) Å (Pr1···Pr1C), respectively (c).

The dihedral angles of δ, ε, and ζ for HBTA- ligand are 48.74(7)°, 42.33(2)°, and 6.70(7)°, respectively, which indicates that the imidazole ring rotated through the C-C bonds when the carboxyl oxygen atoms coordinated with the metal centers to reduce the steric effect. Besides, the oxalate ions bridged the adjacent PrIII ions, and a 1D [Pr(ox)] n  polymeric chain emerged, with the ox2- separated Pr⋅⋅⋅Pr distances of 6.388(7) Å (Pr1⋅⋅⋅Pr1B), and 6.450(1) Å (Pr1⋅⋅⋅Pr1C), respectively (c).

elements.content: Sharing the PrIII ions, those 1D chains of [Pr­(ox)] n and [Pr­(HBTA)] n chains finally constructed a 3D framework with an opening area about 15.011(5) × 10.692(0) Å2 along the ab plane (d). And the 3D architecture can be viewed as the normal 4-connected 66-dia net (e,f). The larger channels of the 3D structure make the interpenetration appear. Two adjacent 3D nets interspersed with each other, giving a 3D 2-fold interpenetrated 66-dia framework ultimately by treating the PrIII ions as 4-connected nodes (g).

elements.content: Complexes 7 and 8 are isostructural, and the structure of complex 7 was selected as a representative herein. Complex 7 crystallized in the monoclinic C2/c. There are one EuIII ion, one BTA2– ligand, a half of sulfate ions, and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit (a). Each EuIII ion is coordinated two nitrogen atoms (N2 and N3), three carboxyl oxygen atoms of O1, O3, and O4, two sulfate oxygen atoms (O5, O6F), and the O7 from coordinated H2O, displaying a distorted [EuN2O6] bicapped trigonal prismatic geometry with the O3, O5, O7, O6F, N2, and N3 form a bigonal prism, and O1, and O4 act as capping atoms (b). Besides, the Eu–O band distances are in the scope of 1.936(4)–2.670(2) Å, and the Eu–N bond distances are 1.936(4), 2.670(2) Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [Ln(BTA)(SO4)0.5(H2O)] n  (Ln = Eu for 7, and Tb for 8)

Complexes 7 and 8 are isostructural, and the structure of complex 7 was selected as a representative herein. Complex 7 crystallized in the monoclinic C2/c. There are one EuIII ion, one BTA2- ligand, a half of sulfate ions, and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit (a). Each EuIII ion is coordinated two nitrogen atoms (N2 and N3), three carboxyl oxygen atoms of O1, O3, and O4, two sulfate oxygen atoms (O5, O6F), and the O7 from coordinated H2O, displaying a distorted [EuN2O6] bicapped trigonal prismatic geometry with the O3, O5, O7, O6F, N2, and N3 form a bigonal prism, and O1, and O4 act as capping atoms (b). Besides, the Eu-O band distances are in the scope of 1.936(4)-2.670(2) Å, and the Eu-N bond distances are 1.936(4), 2.670(2) Å, respectively.

(b) Coordination geometry of Eu1 in 7. (c) The 2D [Eu2(BTA)3] n sheet. (d) 3D framework of 7 along the b axis. (e) 3D (4,5)-connected (44·62)­(44·66) topology of 7 (green spheres: Eu­(III) ions, blue spheres: BAT2– ligands, green bonds: sulfate ions). (f) Tiling featured net of the 3D architecture of 7.

(b) Coordination geometry of Eu1 in 7. (c) The 2D [Eu2(BTA)3] n  sheet. (d) 3D framework of 7 along the b axis. (e) 3D (4,5)-connected (44⋅62)(44⋅66) topology of 7 (green spheres: Eu(III) ions, blue spheres: BAT2- ligands, green bonds: sulfate ions). (f) Tiling featured net of the 3D architecture of 7.

elements.content: In complex 7, the H2BTA ligand adopted two different coordination modes, μ4-(η1)-κ1 N-(η1)-κ1 N mode (Mode II) and μ4-(η2)-κ1 N-(η2)-κ1 N mode (Mode V). Although the Mode II BTA2– ligand adopted the same mode like that in 1, the dihedral angles for δ, ε, and ζ are 62.30(1)°, 62.30(1)°, and 0.00(0)°, indicating the BTA2– ligand holds a different rotation between the aromatic rings. Mode II BTA2– ligand linked with four EuIII ions through the two imidazole N atoms and the monodentate η1 carboxyl groups. And the Mode V BTA2– ligand connected with four EuIII ions with two imidazole N atoms and two chelating η2 carboxyl groups, with the δ, ε, and ζ values of 41.31(3)°, 41.31(3)°, and 0.00(0)°, respectively. From two kinds of BTA2– ligands coordinated with EuIII ions finally emerged a 2D [Eu­(BTA)] n sheet (c), with adjacent Eu···Eu distances of 10.985(1) Å (Eu1···Eu1B), and 11.437(71) Å (Eu1···Eu1A). The SO4 2– anion bridged the neighboring [Eu­(BTA)] n sheets and successfully constructed a 3D framework (d), in which the SO4 2– anion separated the Eu···Eu distance of 5.967(0) Å (Eu1···Eu1F). From the point of topology, the final 3D architecture can be simplified to be a (4,5)-connected (44·62)­(44·66) net, in which the EuIII ions are as 4-connected nodes, and the BTA2– ligands are as 5-connected nodes, respectively (e,f).
elements.clean_text: In complex 7, the H2BTA ligand adopted two different coordination modes, μ4-(η1)-κ1 N-(η1)-κ1 N mode (Mode II) and μ4-(η2)-κ1 N-(η2)-κ1 N mode (Mode V). Although the Mode II BTA2- ligand adopted the same mode like that in 1, the dihedral angles for δ, ε, and ζ are 62.30(1)°, 62.30(1)°, and 0.00(0)°, indicating the BTA2- ligand holds a different rotation between the aromatic rings. Mode II BTA2- ligand linked with four EuIII ions through the two imidazole N atoms and the monodentate η1 carboxyl groups. And the Mode V BTA2- ligand connected with four EuIII ions with two imidazole N atoms and two chelating η2 carboxyl groups, with the δ, ε, and ζ values of 41.31(3)°, 41.31(3)°, and 0.00(0)°, respectively. From two kinds of BTA2- ligands coordinated with EuIII ions finally emerged a 2D [Eu(BTA)] n  sheet (c), with adjacent Eu⋅⋅⋅Eu distances of 10.985(1) Å (Eu1⋅⋅⋅Eu1B), and 11.437(71) Å (Eu1⋅⋅⋅Eu1A). The SO4 2- anion bridged the neighboring [Eu(BTA)] n  sheets and successfully constructed a 3D framework (d), in which the SO4 2- anion separated the Eu⋅⋅⋅Eu distance of 5.967(0) Å (Eu1⋅⋅⋅Eu1F). From the point of topology, the final 3D architecture can be simplified to be a (4,5)-connected (44⋅62)(44⋅66) net, in which the EuIII ions are as 4-connected nodes, and the BTA2- ligands are as 5-connected nodes, respectively (e,f).

elements.content: It is interestingly to note that although all eight LnCPs were constructed from the H2BTA ligand, Ln­(NO3)3·6H2O with the help of oxalate or sulfate ions under similar reaction conditions, they exhibited entirely different 3D architectures, which mainly are attributed to lanthanide contraction as well as the influences of anions. The H2BTA ligand adopted five coordination modes in the assembly of 1–8 (), with two carboxyl groups completely deprotonated and participated in coordination for all modes, whereas two imidazole N atoms of the BTA2– ligand linked with one LnIII ion in Mode I, two Ln ions in Mode II, Mode III, and Mode V, no ion in Mode IV, respectively. And the dihedral angles of BTA2–/HBTA– ligands indicated that the ligand twisted when coordinating with the LnIII ions (). In 1, the BTA2– ligands adopted μ4-(η2)-κ1 N-(η1:η1) (Mode I) and μ4-(η1)-κ1 N-(η1)-κ1 N (Mode II) coordination modes, linking with LaIII ions, and successfully constructed a 3D [La2(BTA)2] n network with 3D (42.6)2(42.84)­(43.6.86)2 topology. For complex 2, each μ5-(η1)-κ1 N-(η1:η1)-κ1 N (Mode III) BTA2– ligand contacted with five NdIII ions, giving a 3D [Nd­(BTA)]n network, which can be simplified to be a 3D (412.612.84)­(46)2 net. While in the isostructural of complexes 3–6, one imidazole N attached the hydrogen atom, and each HBTA– ligand connected two LnIII ions through two chelating η2 carboxyl groups, leaving a 1D zigzag [Ln­(HBTA)] n chain. In complexes 7 and 8, two kinds completely deprotonated BTA2– ligands attached the LnIII ions by adopting μ4-(η1)-κ1 N-(η1)-κ1 N (Mode II) and μ4-(η2)-κ1 N-(η2)-κ1 N (Mode V) coordination modes, finally building a 2D (44.62)-sql [Ln2(BTA)3] n sheet.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Comparison

It is interestingly to note that although all eight LnCPs were constructed from the H2BTA ligand, Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O with the help of oxalate or sulfate ions under similar reaction conditions, they exhibited entirely different 3D architectures, which mainly are attributed to lanthanide contraction as well as the influences of anions. The H2BTA ligand adopted five coordination modes in the assembly of 1-8 (), with two carboxyl groups completely deprotonated and participated in coordination for all modes, whereas two imidazole N atoms of the BTA2- ligand linked with one LnIII ion in Mode I, two Ln ions in Mode II, Mode III, and Mode V, no ion in Mode IV, respectively. And the dihedral angles of BTA2-/HBTA- ligands indicated that the ligand twisted when coordinating with the LnIII ions (). In 1, the BTA2- ligands adopted μ4-(η2)-κ1 N-(η1:η1) (Mode I) and μ4-(η1)-κ1 N-(η1)-κ1 N (Mode II) coordination modes, linking with LaIII ions, and successfully constructed a 3D [La2(BTA)2] n  network with 3D (42.6)2(42.84)(43.6.86)2 topology. For complex 2, each μ5-(η1)-κ1 N-(η1:η1)-κ1 N (Mode III) BTA2- ligand contacted with five NdIII ions, giving a 3D [Nd(BTA)]n network, which can be simplified to be a 3D (412.612.84)(46)2 net. While in the isostructural of complexes 3-6, one imidazole N attached the hydrogen atom, and each HBTA- ligand connected two LnIII ions through two chelating η2 carboxyl groups, leaving a 1D zigzag [Ln(HBTA)] n  chain. In complexes 7 and 8, two kinds completely deprotonated BTA2- ligands attached the LnIII ions by adopting μ4-(η1)-κ1 N-(η1)-κ1 N (Mode II) and μ4-(η2)-κ1 N-(η2)-κ1 N (Mode V) coordination modes, finally building a 2D (44.62)-sql [Ln2(BTA)3] n  sheet.

δ, ε, and ζ corresponding to the dihedral angles between rings of A/B, B/C, and A/C, respectively.

On the other hand, the oxalate and sulfate ions play crucial roles in the assembly of titled LnCPs. As can be seen in , the ox2– apply two different coordination types (μ2-κ1:κ1:κ1:κ1 type (Type I) and μ4-κ1:κ2:κ1:κ2 type (Type II)) in the formation of complex 1, joined with LaIII ions, granting an unprecedented 2D [La2(ox)3] n sheet, while in complex 2, the ox2– just bridged two neighboring NdIII ions, leaving a [Nd2(ox)] linker. For complexes 3–6, the ox2– connected with adjacent LaIII ions, providing the 1D [Ln­(ox)] n chains. When the sulfate ions were introduced to replace the oxalate ions in the formation of complexes 7 and 8, SO4 2– acts as the bridger linked two LaIII ions, giving [La2(SO4)] linkers.

For complexes 3-6, the ox2- connected with adjacent LaIII ions, providing the 1D [Ln(ox)] n  chains. When the sulfate ions were introduced to replace the oxalate ions in the formation of complexes 7 and 8, SO4 2- acts as the bridger linked two LaIII ions, giving [La2(SO4)] linkers.

The Ln-(H)­BTA motifs and Ln-ox/SO4 motifs work together by sharing the LnIII ions, finally constructing series LnCPs with structures ranging from binuclear La2 SBUs based (3,3,4,9)-connected (411.55.614.75.8)2(42.5)2(43)2(44.62) net (1), binuclear Nd2 SBUs based (4,10)-connected (412.516.612.75)­(46)2 net (2), 2-fold interpenetrated 4-connected (66)-dia net (3–6), to (4,5)-connected (44.62) (44.66) net (7, 8). In summary, the versatility of the bifunctional H2BTA and the bridged oxalate/sulfate ions contributes to the structure diversity of obtained LnCPs.

In summary, the versatility of the bifunctional H2BTA and the bridged oxalate/sulfate ions contributes to the structure diversity of obtained LnCPs.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses measurements of complexes 1–8 were performed and given in Figure S3. For complex 1, the first weight loss below 140 °C can be attributed to the coordinated water loss (obsd: 5.67%; calcd: 5.95%); above this temperature, the whole structure began to collapse with the residual weight of ca. 54.3% at 800 °C. For complex 2, the release of water molecules (free and coordinated) took place below 190 °C (obsd: 3.92%; calcd: 3.58%), and then the framework broke down at around 380 °C, finally leaving a residual weight of ca. 43.8% at 800 °C. The curve of 3 was selected as respective of isomorphism 3–6 discussed here, the initial weight loss of 3.4% in 80–185 °C implying the loss of lattice water (calcd: 3.3%). The second weight loss entails the pyrolysis behaviors of organic ligands with the residual weight of ca. 36.0% at 800 °C. Complexes 7 and 8 show similar thermal degradation curves, with the first weight loss of 3.7% (calcd: 3.5%) for 7, and 3.6% (calcd: 3.5%) for 8 that can be ascribed to the removal of coordinated water molecules. And then the frameworks can be stable, existing until the temperature up to about 380 °C and finally giving the residual weight at 800 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analyses

Thermogravimetric analyses measurements of complexes 1-8 were performed and given in Figure S3. For complex 1, the first weight loss below 140 °C can be attributed to the coordinated water loss (obsd: 5.67%; calcd: 5.95%); above this temperature, the whole structure began to collapse with the residual weight of ca. 54.3% at 800 °C. For complex 2, the release of water molecules (free and coordinated) took place below 190 °C (obsd: 3.92%; calcd: 3.58%), and then the framework broke down at around 380 °C, finally leaving a residual weight of ca. 43.8% at 800 °C. The curve of 3 was selected as respective of isomorphism 3-6 discussed here, the initial weight loss of 3.4% in 80-185 °C implying the loss of lattice water (calcd: 3.3%). The second weight loss entails the pyrolysis behaviors of organic ligands with the residual weight of ca. 36.0% at 800 °C. Complexes 7 and 8 show similar thermal degradation curves, with the first weight loss of 3.7% (calcd: 3.5%) for 7, and 3.6% (calcd: 3.5%) for 8 that can be ascribed to the removal of coordinated water molecules. And then the frameworks can be stable, existing until the temperature up to about 380 °C and finally giving the residual weight at 800 °C.

elements.content: Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility of complex 2 was examined with the temperature range from 1.8 K to 300 K at 1000 Oe. As can be seen in , the χm T value at 300 K is 1.55 cm3 K mol–1, close to the expected value of 1.64 cm3 K mol–1 for non-interacting NdIII ion in the ground state with g = 8/11. The χm T product declines continuously to 0.78 cm3 K mol–1 at 1.8 K as the temperature decreases. The temperature dependence χM followed the Curie–Weiss law χM = C/(T – θ) with C = 1.62 cm3 K mol–1, θ = −15.64 K (). And the χm –1–T curve is given in Figure S4. The thermal depopulation of the crystal-field energy levels of the multiplet makes a contribution to the magnetic behavior of 2. And the negative value of θ also indicates the antiferromagnetic interactions of the nearest NdIII ions.

Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility of complex 2 was examined with the temperature range from 1.8 K to 300 K at 1000 Oe. As can be seen in , the χm T value at 300 K is 1.55 cm3 K mol-1, close to the expected value of 1.64 cm3 K mol-1 for non-interacting NdIII ion in the ground state with g = 8/11. The χm T product declines continuously to 0.78 cm3 K mol-1 at 1.8 K as the temperature decreases. The temperature dependence χM followed the Curie-Weiss law χM = C/(T - θ) with C = 1.62 cm3 K mol-1, θ = -15.64 K (). And the χm -1-T curve is given in Figure S4. The thermal depopulation of the crystal-field energy levels of the multiplet makes a contribution to the magnetic behavior of 2. And the negative value of θ also indicates the antiferromagnetic interactions of the nearest NdIII ions.

elements.content: The solid state fluorescence spectrum of 1–8 and the free H2BTA ligand were examined at room temperature. As shown in , H2BTA displays an emission peak at 438 nm upon excitation at 350 nm, with the calculated triplet level of 22 826 cm–1 (), which can be attributed to the π*−π transition of the p electrons of the aromatic rings. And when the H2BTA ligand coordinated with the LaIII ion, the complex of 1 (LaCP) exhibits green-blue emission centered at 428 nm (λex = 350 nm) and has a blue shift of 10 nm, which can be assigned to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The luminescent lifetime of 1 (LaCP) was measured from the decay profile (Figure S5) and is well fitted with the double exponential function with an average luminescent lifetime τ = 2.35 ms, with τ1 = 0.39 ms (f 1 = 15.187), τ2 = 2.7 ms (f 2 = 84.813), and χ2 = 1.247. Besides, the quantum yield Φf of 1 is 2.40%.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The solid state fluorescence spectrum of 1-8 and the free H2BTA ligand were examined at room temperature. As shown in , H2BTA displays an emission peak at 438 nm upon excitation at 350 nm, with the calculated triplet level of 22826 cm-1 (), which can be attributed to the π*-π transition of the p electrons of the aromatic rings. And when the H2BTA ligand coordinated with the LaIII ion, the complex of 1 (LaCP) exhibits green-blue emission centered at 428 nm (λex = 350 nm) and has a blue shift of 10 nm, which can be assigned to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The luminescent lifetime of 1 (LaCP) was measured from the decay profile (Figure S5) and is well fitted with the double exponential function with an average luminescent lifetime τ = 2.35 ms, with τ1 = 0.39 ms (f 1 = 15.187), τ2 = 2.7 ms (f 2 = 84.813), and χ2 = 1.247. Besides, the quantum yield Φf of 1 is 2.40%.

The NdIII based materials are the most promising near-infrared luminescent materials, which can be widely used in the field of optical telecommunication as well as laser systems. Upon excitation at 315 nm, the emission spectra of 2 (NdCP) exhibits three strong bands at 896, 1064, and 1337 nm in the NIR region, which are attributed to the transitions of 4F3/2 → 4IJ with J = 9/2, 11/2, and 13/2, respectively (). The calculated triplet energy of the above-mentioned peaks is close to the theoretical values of the NdIII ion, according to the historical work of W. T. Carnall and the review of E. G. Moore. And the main energy level assignments of the titled complexes are listed in .

elements.content: The PrIII ion based luminescent coordination polymers have been rarely reported. As claimed by Decadt, there are two emissive electronic states for the PrIII ion, and the emission can occur for both of them. We tested the emission spectra of 3 (PrCP) under excitation at 400 nm, and the bands at 458 and 499 nm derived from the π*−π transition of the p electrons, and the other bands can be assigned to the energy transitions of PrIII ion at 481 (3P0 → 3H4), 524 (3P0 → 3H5), 614 (3P0 → 3H6 and 1D2 → 3H4), 646 (3P0 → 3F2), and 682 nm (1D2 → 3H5) ( and ). As shown in Figure S6, the decay curve indicated that the average luminescent lifetime of 3 is 0.94 ms, with τ1 = 0.19 ms (f 1 = 42.486), τ2 = 1.5 ms (f 2 = 57.514), and χ2 = 1.181, fitted well to the biexponential function. And the quantum yield Φf is 5.36%.

As shown in Figure S6, the decay curve indicated that the average luminescent lifetime of 3 is 0.94 ms, with τ1 = 0.19 ms (f 1 = 42.486), τ2 = 1.5 ms (f 2 = 57.514), and χ2 = 1.181, fitted well to the biexponential function. elements.content: The doping LnIII ions strategy has been widely considered for white-light emitting, but only several single components of white light emitting have been reported to date. For 4 (SmCP), under the excitation of 400 nm, a broad band of 375–475 nm centered at 450 nm derived from the π*−π transition of organic ligands, and three sharp bands at 562, 601, and 642 nm originating from the transitions of 4G5/2 → 6HJ (J = 5/2, 7/2, and 9/2) () have occurred, with the characteristic colors of those peaks being green, orange, and red, respectively (). Considering the remaining ligand fluorescence as well as the characteristic luminescence of the SmIII ions, SmCP can generate single component white light material, with the CIE color coordinates of (0.33, 0.30), according to the 1931 CIE chromaticity diagram, closely with the standard white light of (0.33, 0.33). The average luminescent lifetime of the white light SmCP is 0.35 ms, with τ1 = 0.19 ms (f 1 = 70.888), τ2 = 0.75 ms (f 2 = 29.112), and χ2 = 1.091, fitting well the biexponential function (Figure S7). And the quantum yield Φf is 8.27%.

elements.content: When excited at 400 nm, complex 5 (DyCP) emitted one remaining ligand fluorescence of 417 nm with a shoulder of 436 nm, and two typical bands of DyIII ion at 481 and 572 nm, which are assigned to 4F9/2 → 6HJ (J = 15/2 and 13/2) transitions ( and ). And the CIE color coordinates is (0.18, 0.15) for 5 (DyCP), indicating it is a blue fluorescent material. The decay curve of the luminescent showing the average lifetime is 1.59 ms, with τ1 = 0.34 ms (f 1 = 39.403), τ2 = 2.4 ms (f 2 = 60.597), and χ2 = 1.181, fitting well the double exponential function (Figure S8). And the quantum yield Φf is 25.50%.

elements.content: As the most promising red emitting phosphors, the EuIII complexes have been fully investigated for the sharp emission at about 615 nm. For 6 (EuCP-1), under excitation at 395 nm, the emission spectra shows intense bands at 591, 614, and 691 nm, referring to the energy level diagrams proven by W. T. Carnall; those bands can be attributed to the 5D0 → 7FJ transitions with J = 1, 2, and 4, respectively, while the intensity of 5D0 → 7F3 transition at 649 nm is too weak to be observed (). In addition, the intensity of 5D0 → 7F2 transition is much stronger than that of 5D0 → 7F1 transition. The complex 7 (EuCP-2) displays a similar emission spectra with 6, the intense bands appearing at about 590, 613, 651, and 699 nm, which are attributed to the transitions of 5D0 → 7FJ with J = 1, 2, 3, and 4, respectively. And the CIE color coordinates are (0.58, 0.32) for 6 (EuCP-1), and (0.62, 0.34) for 7 (EuCP-2), indicating that they are good candidates as a red light emitter. As shown in Figure S9 and Figure S10, two EuCPs display similar decay curves, both fitted well with the double exponential function, with the average photoluminescent lifetimes being 0.34 ms (τ1 = 0.30 ms, f 1 = 70.750, τ2 = 0.42 ms, f 2 = 29.250, and χ2 = 1.286) for 6 (EuCP-1), and 0.48 ms (τ1 = 0.47 ms, f 1 = 95.243, τ2 = 0.60 ms, f 2 = 4.757, and χ2 = 1.121) for 7 (EuCP-2), respectively. Besides, the quantum yields Φf for 6 and 7 are 7.89%, and 3.33%, respectively.

elements.content: And under excitation at 315 nm, the emission spectrum of 8 (TbCP) exhibits sharp bands at 487, 544, 583, and 620 nm, which correspond to the characteristic transitions of 5D4 → 7FJ of the TbIII ion with J = 6, 5, 4, and 3, respectively (). The most intense emission at 544 nm corresponds to 5D4 → 7F5. And the CIE color coordinates are (0.29, 0.56) for 8 (TbCP). As can be seen in Figure S11, the decay curve of 8 (TbCP) fitted well with the double exponential function, with the average photoluminescent lifetime being 0.36 ms (τ1 = 0.31 ms, f 1 = 81.732, τ2 = 0.57 ms, f 2 = 18.268, and χ2 = 1.137). Besides, the quantum yields Φf for 8 is 6.74%.

elements.content: In general, on the basis of the designed bifunctional 1,4-bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­terephthalic acid and oxalate/sulfate ions, a series of 3D lanthanide coordination polymers have been designed with the structure ranging from a (3,3,4,9)-connected (411.55.614.75.8)2­(42.5)2(43)2­(44.62) net, (4,10)-connected (412.516.612.75)­(46)2 net, (4,5)-connected (44·62)­(44·66) net, to 2-fold interpenetrated 4-connected (66)-dia net. Photoluminscence inverstigation shows the 2 (NdCP) is a good near-infrared luminescent material, 4 (SmCP) is a rarely reported single component white light emitting material, 6 (EuCP-1) and 7 (EuCP-2) show typical red emission, which can be used as red emitting phosphor, while 8 (TbCP) shows typical green emission, which can be used as a green emitting phosphor as well as fluorescent labeling. Further work on the LnCPs are underway in our lab.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In general, on the basis of the designed bifunctional 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)terephthalic acid and oxalate/sulfate ions, a series of 3D lanthanide coordination polymers have been designed with the structure ranging from a (3,3,4,9)-connected (411.55.614.75.8)2(42.5)2(43)2(44.62) net, (4,10)-connected (412.516.612.75)(46)2 net, (4,5)-connected (44⋅62)(44⋅66) net, to 2-fold interpenetrated 4-connected (66)-dia net. Photoluminscence inverstigation shows the 2 (NdCP) is a good near-infrared luminescent material, 4 (SmCP) is a rarely reported single component white light emitting material, 6 (EuCP-1) and 7 (EuCP-2) show typical red emission, which can be used as red emitting phosphor, while 8 (TbCP) shows typical green emission, which can be used as a green emitting phosphor as well as fluorescent labeling. Further work on the LnCPs are underway in our lab.

CCDC 1471606-1471613 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif, or by emailing data_request@ccdc.cam.ac.uk, or by contacting The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: +44 1223 336033.

p-Xylene (10.6 g, 0.1 mol), I2 (0.1 g), and 30% H2O2 (10 mL) were dissolved in 1000 mL of CH2Cl2 and were cooled below 5 °C in an icewater bath. Br2 (11.3 mL, 0.22 mol) was dropped in the cooled solution and stirred for 24 h. Then saturated sodium hyposulfite solution was added to remove redundant Br2 and I2. The separated organic solution was reduced to 200 mL by evaporation. Colorless crystalline 2,5-dibromo-p-xylene (II) was obtained with a yield of 95%. Anal. (%) calcd. for C8H8Br2: C, 36.40; H, 3.05. Found: C, 36.34; H, 2.99.

Synthesis of 2,5-Dibromoterephthalic Acid (<bold>III</bold>)

The mixture of 2,5-dibromo-p-xylene (II) (0.1 mol, 26.2 g) and 100 mL of tert-butanol in 1000 mL of H2O was refluxed, and then potassium permanganate (76 g, 0.48 mol) was slowly added. After the mixture was refluxed a further 4 h, ethanol was added to remove redundant potassium permanganate. The filtrated solution was acidified with the concentrated HCl, and then a white predicate was obtained, which was recrystallized with DMF. The yield is 65%. Anal. (%) calcd. for C8H4Br2O4: C, 29.66; H, 1.24. Found: C, 29.47; H, 1.11.

Synthesis of Ethyl 2,5-Dibromoterephthalate (<bold>IV</bold>)

2,5-Dibromoterephthalic acid (0.05 mol, 16.0 g) was suspended in 500 mL of ethanol with 20 mL of H2SO4 and was refluxed overnight, and then the mixture was poured into 1000 mL of icewater. The solution was neutralized with ammonium water and extracted with CH2Cl2 three times. Obtained organic solution was concentrated, and a colorless crystalline product was collected with 90% yield. Anal. (%) calcd. for C12H12Br2O4: C, 37.93; H, 3.18. Found: C, 37.72; H, 3.08.

Synthesis of Diethyl 1,4-Bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­terephthalate (<bold>V</bold>)

The mixture of IV (0.01 mol, 3.8 g), imidazole (0.1 mol, 6.8 g), CuSO4 (0.5 g), and K2CO3 (0.1 mol, 13.8 g) was refluxed for 4 h and was dissolved in 500 mL of EtOH. The solution was decoloured with activated carbon and concentrated to 100 mL. Crude product was obtained and recrystallized with mixed solvent of ethyl acetate and DMF. Anal. (%) calcd. for C18H18N4O4: C, 61.01; H, 5.12; N, 15.81. Found: C, 60.85; H, 5.03; N, 15.65.

Synthesis of 1,4-Bis­(imidazol-1-yl)­terephthalic Acid (H<sub>2</sub>BTA) (<bold>VI</bold>)

The mixture of V (0.01 mol, 3.5 g) and 20 mL of concentrated HCl in 100 mL of H2O was refluxed overnight and filtrated. The obtained precipitate was recrystallized DMF to obtain a white powder. EI-MS: m/z [M – H]−, 297.07 (calcd for C14H10N4O4, 298.07). Anal. (%) calcd. for C14H10N4O4: C, 56.38; H, 3.38; N, 18.78. Found: C, 56.22; H, 3.16; N, 18.60.

Syntheses of H<sub>2</sub>BTA based LnCPsSynthesis of [La<sub>2</sub>(BTA)<sub>1.5</sub>(ox)<sub>1.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of H2BTA (0.15 mmol, 0.045 g), La­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.20 mmol, 0.087 g), K2(C2O4)·H2O (0.20 mmol, 0.037 g), NaOH (0.30 mmol, 0.012 g), and 8 mL of H2O in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel was put into an oven at 150 °C for 3 days, and then was slow cooled to room temperature with a descent rate of 10 °C/h. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained with the yield of ca. 67% (based on H2BTA). Anal. Calcd for C24H18La2N6O15: C, 31.74; H, 2.00; N, 9.25 (%). Found: C, 32.03; H, 2.21; N, 9.16 (%). IR (cm–1, KBr): 3128 (m), 1603 (vs), 1511 (vs), 1429 (vs), 1379 (s), 1310 (s), 1244 (m), 1068 (m), 977 (m), 926 (m), 833 (m), 786 (m), 735 (m), 657 (m).

Synthesis of [Nd­(BTA)­(ox)<sub>0.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

H2BTA (0.15 mmol, 0.045 g), Nd­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.20 mmol, 0.089 g), K2(C2O4)·H2O (0.20 mmol, 0.037 g), NaOH (0.30 mmol, 0.012 g), 8 mL of H2O and 4 mL of CH3OH were successively placed into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. Then the mixture was kept to 150 °C for 3 days and then slowly cooled to ambient temperature with a descent rate of 10 °C/h. Violet block crystals of 2 were obtained with the yield of 71% (based on H2BTA). Anal. Calcd for C15H10N4NdO7: C, 35.85; H, 2.01; N, 11.15 (%). Found: C, 35.63; H, 2.19; N, 10.96 (%). IR (cm–1, KBr): 3485 (m), 1668 (m),1598 (s),1431 (m), 1376 (s), 1312 (m), 1155 (vs), 1065 (vs), 991 (s), 844 (m), 742 (m), 644 (m).

Synthesis of {[Ln­(HBTA)­(ox)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)]·<italic>x</italic>H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (Ln = Pr for <bold>3</bold> (<italic>x</italic> = 0), Sm for <bold>4</bold> (<italic>x</italic> = 0), Dy for <bold>5</bold> (<italic>x</italic> = 1.5), and Eu for <bold>6</bold> (<italic>x</italic> = 1))

The synthesis processes of 3–6 were similar to that of complex 1, except that the La­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.20 mmol, 0.087 g) was insteaded by Pr­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.20 mmol, 0.087 g) for 3, Sm­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.20 mmol, 0.089 g) for 4, Dy­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.20 mmol, 0.091 g) for 5, and Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.20 mmol, 0.089 g) for 6. Yield of 73% for 3 (based on H2BTA). Anal. Calcd for C16H11N4O9Pr: C, 35.31; H, 2.04; N, 10.30 (%). Found: C, 35.67; H, 2.13; N, 10.73 (%). IR (cm–1, KBr): 3122 (s), 1664 (m), 1567 (s), 1505 (m), 1415 (s), 1371 (s), 1313 (m), 1240 (m), 1110 (m), 1066 (s), 976 (m), 925 (m), 838 (m), 793 (m), 746 (m), 659 (m). For 4, the yield is 74% (based on H2BTA). Anal. Calcd for C16H12N4O9Sm: C, 34.65; H, 2.18; N, 10.10 (%). Found: C, 34.91; H, 2.29; N, 10.18 (%). IR (cm–1, KBr): 3120 (m), 1671 (m), 1576 (s), 1434 (m), 1381 (vs), 1313 (s), 1128 (m), 1066 (s), 911 (w), 845 (s), 797 (s), 741 (s), 646 (m). For 5, the yield is 51% (based on H2BTA). Anal. Calcd for C16H14DyN4O10.5: C, 32.42; H, 2.38; N, 9.45 (%). Found: C, 32.66; H, 2.71; N, 9.71 (%). IR (cm–1, KBr): 3117 (s), 1673 (m), 1574 (s), 1437 (m), 1384 (s), 1313 (s), 1066 (s), 848 (m), 797 (s), 741 (m), 646 (m). For 6, the yield is 68% (based on H2BTA). Anal. Calcd for C16H14EuN4O10: C, 33.46; H, 2.46; N, 9.76 (%). Found: C, 33.73; H, 2.72; N, 9.63 (%). IR (cm–1, KBr): 3120 (s), 1671 (m), 1580 (s), 1434 (s), 1381 (s), 1314 (s), 1066 (s), 845 (m), 797 (s), 742 (m), 647 (w).

Synthesis of [Ln­(BTA)­(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>0.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (Ln = Eu for <bold>7</bold>, and Tb for <bold>8</bold>)

A mixture of H2BTA (0.15 mmol, 0.066 g) and Ln­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.20 mmol, 0.092 g) was added in 8 mL of H2O, and then the pH value was adjusted to about 5.5 by using the NaOH and H2SO4. After being stirred for a half hour, the mixture was transferred into the 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 150 °C for 5 days, and then slowly cooled to ambient temperature with a descent rate of 10 °C/h. Colorless block crystals of 7 were obtained with the yield of ca. 67% (based on H2BTA). Anal. Calcd for C28H20Eu2N8O14S: C, 32.70; H, 1.96; N, 10.89 (%). Found: C, 32.82; H, 2.01; N, 10.94 (%). IR (cm–1, KBr): 3196 (m), 1694 (vs), 1603 (m), 1529 (vs), 1420 (s), 1357 (vs), 1210 (s), 1120 (m), 892 (m), 765 (m), 680 (m). For complex 8, the yield is 73% (based on H2BTA). Anal. Calcd for C28H20N8O14STb2: C, 32.26; H, 1.93; N, 10.75 (%). Found: C, 32.41; H, 2.07; N, 10.94 (%). IR (cm–1, KBr): 3453 (m), 3134 (m), 1621 (s), 1530 (vs), 1393 (s), 1311 (s), 1266 (m), 1129 (w), 1065 (s), 956 (m),774 (w), 728 (w).

cln_elements.content:
Sharing the PrIII ions, those 1D chains of [Pr­(ox)] n and [Pr­(HBTA)] n chains finally constructed a 3D framework with an opening area about 15.011(5) × 10.692(0) Å2 along the ab plane (d). And the 3D architecture can be viewed as the normal 4-connected 66-dia net (e,f). The larger channels of the 3D structure make the interpenetration appear. Two adjacent 3D nets interspersed with each other, giving a 3D 2-fold interpenetrated 66-dia framework ultimately by treating the PrIII ions as 4-connected nodes (g).

Thermogravimetric Analyses

Thermogravimetric analyses measurements of complexes 1–8 were performed and given in Figure S3. For complex 1, the first weight loss below 140 °C can be attributed to the coordinated water loss (obsd: 5.67%; calcd: 5.95%); above this temperature, the whole structure began to collapse with the residual weight of ca. 54.3% at 800 °C. For complex 2, the release of water molecules (free and coordinated) took place below 190 °C (obsd: 3.92%; calcd: 3.58%), and then the framework broke down at around 380 °C, finally leaving a residual weight of ca. 43.8% at 800 °C. The curve of 3 was selected as respective of isomorphism 3–6 discussed here, the initial weight loss of 3.4% in 80–185 °C implying the loss of lattice water (calcd: 3.3%). The second weight loss entails the pyrolysis behaviors of organic ligands with the residual weight of ca. 36.0% at 800 °C. Complexes 7 and 8 show similar thermal degradation curves, with the first weight loss of 3.7% (calcd: 3.5%) for 7, and 3.6% (calcd: 3.5%) for 8 that can be ascribed to the removal of coordinated water molecules. And then the frameworks can be stable, existing until the temperature up to about 380 °C and finally giving the residual weight at 800 °C.

Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility of complex 2 was examined with the temperature range from 1.8 K to 300 K at 1000 Oe. As can be seen in , the χm T value at 300 K is 1.55 cm3 K mol–1, close to the expected value of 1.64 cm3 K mol–1 for non-interacting NdIII ion in the ground state with g = 8/11. The χm T product declines continuously to 0.78 cm3 K mol–1 at 1.8 K as the temperature decreases. The temperature dependence χM followed the Curie–Weiss law χM = C/(T – θ) with C = 1.62 cm3 K mol–1, θ = −15.64 K (). And the χm –1–T curve is given in Figure S4. The thermal depopulation of the crystal-field energy levels of the multiplet makes a contribution to the magnetic behavior of 2. And the negative value of θ also indicates the antiferromagnetic interactions of the nearest NdIII ions.

Luminescent Properties

The solid state fluorescence spectrum of 1–8 and the free H2BTA ligand were examined at room temperature. As shown in , H2BTA displays an emission peak at 438 nm upon excitation at 350 nm, with the calculated triplet level of 22 826 cm–1 (), which can be attributed to the π*−π transition of the p electrons of the aromatic rings. And when the H2BTA ligand coordinated with the LaIII ion, the complex of 1 (LaCP) exhibits green-blue emission centered at 428 nm (λex = 350 nm) and has a blue shift of 10 nm, which can be assigned to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The luminescent lifetime of 1 (LaCP) was measured from the decay profile (Figure S5) and is well fitted with the double exponential function with an average luminescent lifetime τ = 2.35 ms, with τ1 = 0.39 ms (f 1 = 15.187), τ2 = 2.7 ms (f 2 = 84.813), and χ2 = 1.247. Besides, the quantum yield Φf of 1 is 2.40%.

The NdIII based materials are the most promising near-infrared luminescent materials, which can be widely used in the field of optical telecommunication as well as laser systems. Upon excitation at 315 nm, the emission spectra of 2 (NdCP) exhibits three strong bands at 896, 1064, and 1337 nm in the NIR region, which are attributed to the transitions of 4F3/2 → 4IJ with J = 9/2, 11/2, and 13/2, respectively (). The calculated triplet energy of the above-mentioned peaks is close to the theoretical values of the NdIII ion, according to the historical work of W. T. Carnall and the review of E. G. Moore. And the main energy level assignments of the titled complexes are listed in .

The PrIII ion based luminescent coordination polymers have been rarely reported. As claimed by Decadt, there are two emissive electronic states for the PrIII ion, and the emission can occur for both of them. We tested the emission spectra of 3 (PrCP) under excitation at 400 nm, and the bands at 458 and 499 nm derived from the π*−π transition of the p electrons, and the other bands can be assigned to the energy transitions of PrIII ion at 481 (3P0 → 3H4), 524 (3P0 → 3H5), 614 (3P0 → 3H6 and 1D2 → 3H4), 646 (3P0 → 3F2), and 682 nm (1D2 → 3H5) ( and ). As shown in Figure S6, the decay curve indicated that the average luminescent lifetime of 3 is 0.94 ms, with τ1 = 0.19 ms (f 1 = 42.486), τ2 = 1.5 ms (f 2 = 57.514), and χ2 = 1.181, fitted well to the biexponential function. And the quantum yield Φf is 5.36%.

The doping LnIII ions strategy has been widely considered for white-light emitting, but only several single components of white light emitting have been reported to date. For 4 (SmCP), under the excitation of 400 nm, a broad band of 375–475 nm centered at 450 nm derived from the π*−π transition of organic ligands, and three sharp bands at 562, 601, and 642 nm originating from the transitions of 4G5/2 → 6HJ (J = 5/2, 7/2, and 9/2) () have occurred, with the characteristic colors of those peaks being green, orange, and red, respectively (). Considering the remaining ligand fluorescence as well as the characteristic luminescence of the SmIII ions, SmCP can generate single component white light material, with the CIE color coordinates of (0.33, 0.30), according to the 1931 CIE chromaticity diagram, closely with the standard white light of (0.33, 0.33). The average luminescent lifetime of the white light SmCP is 0.35 ms, with τ1 = 0.19 ms (f 1 = 70.888), τ2 = 0.75 ms (f 2 = 29.112), and χ2 = 1.091, fitting well the biexponential function (Figure S7). And the quantum yield Φf is 8.27%.

As the most promising red emitting phosphors, the EuIII complexes have been fully investigated for the sharp emission at about 615 nm. For 6 (EuCP-1), under excitation at 395 nm, the emission spectra shows intense bands at 591, 614, and 691 nm, referring to the energy level diagrams proven by W. T. Carnall; those bands can be attributed to the 5D0 → 7FJ transitions with J = 1, 2, and 4, respectively, while the intensity of 5D0 → 7F3 transition at 649 nm is too weak to be observed (). In addition, the intensity of 5D0 → 7F2 transition is much stronger than that of 5D0 → 7F1 transition. The complex 7 (EuCP-2) displays a similar emission spectra with 6, the intense bands appearing at about 590, 613, 651, and 699 nm, which are attributed to the transitions of 5D0 → 7FJ with J = 1, 2, 3, and 4, respectively. And the CIE color coordinates are (0.58, 0.32) for 6 (EuCP-1), and (0.62, 0.34) for 7 (EuCP-2), indicating that they are good candidates as a red light emitter. As shown in Figure S9 and Figure S10, two EuCPs display similar decay curves, both fitted well with the double exponential function, with the average photoluminescent lifetimes being 0.34 ms (τ1 = 0.30 ms, f 1 = 70.750, τ2 = 0.42 ms, f 2 = 29.250, and χ2 = 1.286) for 6 (EuCP-1), and 0.48 ms (τ1 = 0.47 ms, f 1 = 95.243, τ2 = 0.60 ms, f 2 = 4.757, and χ2 = 1.121) for 7 (EuCP-2), respectively. Besides, the quantum yields Φf for 6 and 7 are 7.89%, and 3.33%, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Sharing the PrIII ions, those 1D chains of [Pr(ox)] n  and [Pr(HBTA)] n  chains finally constructed a 3D framework with an opening area about 15.011(5) × 10.692(0) Å2 along the ab plane (d). And the 3D architecture can be viewed as the normal 4-connected 66-dia net (e,f). The larger channels of the 3D structure make the interpenetration appear. Two adjacent 3D nets interspersed with each other, giving a 3D 2-fold interpenetrated 66-dia framework ultimately by treating the PrIII ions as 4-connected nodes (g).

Thermogravimetric Analyses

Thermogravimetric analyses measurements of complexes 1-8 were performed and given in Figure S3. For complex 1, the first weight loss below 140 °C can be attributed to the coordinated water loss (obsd: 5.67%; calcd: 5.95%); above this temperature, the whole structure began to collapse with the residual weight of ca. 54.3% at 800 °C. For complex 2, the release of water molecules (free and coordinated) took place below 190 °C (obsd: 3.92%; calcd: 3.58%), and then the framework broke down at around 380 °C, finally leaving a residual weight of ca. 43.8% at 800 °C. The curve of 3 was selected as respective of isomorphism 3-6 discussed here, the initial weight loss of 3.4% in 80-185 °C implying the loss of lattice water (calcd: 3.3%). The second weight loss entails the pyrolysis behaviors of organic ligands with the residual weight of ca. 36.0% at 800 °C. Complexes 7 and 8 show similar thermal degradation curves, with the first weight loss of 3.7% (calcd: 3.5%) for 7, and 3.6% (calcd: 3.5%) for 8 that can be ascribed to the removal of coordinated water molecules. And then the frameworks can be stable, existing until the temperature up to about 380 °C and finally giving the residual weight at 800 °C.

Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility of complex 2 was examined with the temperature range from 1.8 K to 300 K at 1000 Oe. As can be seen in , the χm T value at 300 K is 1.55 cm3 K mol-1, close to the expected value of 1.64 cm3 K mol-1 for non-interacting NdIII ion in the ground state with g = 8/11. The χm T product declines continuously to 0.78 cm3 K mol-1 at 1.8 K as the temperature decreases. The temperature dependence χM followed the Curie-Weiss law χM = C/(T - θ) with C = 1.62 cm3 K mol-1, θ = -15.64 K (). And the χm -1-T curve is given in Figure S4. The thermal depopulation of the crystal-field energy levels of the multiplet makes a contribution to the magnetic behavior of 2. And the negative value of θ also indicates the antiferromagnetic interactions of the nearest NdIII ions.

Luminescent Properties

The solid state fluorescence spectrum of 1-8 and the free H2BTA ligand were examined at room temperature. As shown in , H2BTA displays an emission peak at 438 nm upon excitation at 350 nm, with the calculated triplet level of 22826 cm-1 (), which can be attributed to the π*-π transition of the p electrons of the aromatic rings. And when the H2BTA ligand coordinated with the LaIII ion, the complex of 1 (LaCP) exhibits green-blue emission centered at 428 nm (λex = 350 nm) and has a blue shift of 10 nm, which can be assigned to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The luminescent lifetime of 1 (LaCP) was measured from the decay profile (Figure S5) and is well fitted with the double exponential function with an average luminescent lifetime τ = 2.35 ms, with τ1 = 0.39 ms (f 1 = 15.187), τ2 = 2.7 ms (f 2 = 84.813), and χ2 = 1.247. Besides, the quantum yield Φf of 1 is 2.40%.

The NdIII based materials are the most promising near-infrared luminescent materials, which can be widely used in the field of optical telecommunication as well as laser systems. Upon excitation at 315 nm, the emission spectra of 2 (NdCP) exhibits three strong bands at 896, 1064, and 1337 nm in the NIR region, which are attributed to the transitions of 4F3/2 → 4IJ with J = 9/2, 11/2, and 13/2, respectively (). The calculated triplet energy of the above-mentioned peaks is close to the theoretical values of the NdIII ion, according to the historical work of W. T. Carnall and the review of E. G. Moore. And the main energy level assignments of the titled complexes are listed in .

The PrIII ion based luminescent coordination polymers have been rarely reported. As claimed by Decadt, there are two emissive electronic states for the PrIII ion, and the emission can occur for both of them. We tested the emission spectra of 3 (PrCP) under excitation at 400 nm, and the bands at 458 and 499 nm derived from the π*-π transition of the p electrons, and the other bands can be assigned to the energy transitions of PrIII ion at 481 (3P0 → 3H4), 524 (3P0 → 3H5), 614 (3P0 → 3H6 and 1D2 → 3H4), 646 (3P0 → 3F2), and 682 nm (1D2 → 3H5) ( and ). As shown in Figure S6, the decay curve indicated that the average luminescent lifetime of 3 is 0.94 ms, with τ1 = 0.19 ms (f 1 = 42.486), τ2 = 1.5 ms (f 2 = 57.514), and χ2 = 1.181, fitted well to the biexponential function. And the quantum yield Φf is 5.36%.

The doping LnIII ions strategy has been widely considered for white-light emitting, but only several single components of white light emitting have been reported to date. For 4 (SmCP), under the excitation of 400 nm, a broad band of 375-475 nm centered at 450 nm derived from the π*-π transition of organic ligands, and three sharp bands at 562, 601, and 642 nm originating from the transitions of 4G5/2 → 6HJ (J = 5/2, 7/2, and 9/2) () have occurred, with the characteristic colors of those peaks being green, orange, and red, respectively (). Considering the remaining ligand fluorescence as well as the characteristic luminescence of the SmIII ions, SmCP can generate single component white light material, with the CIE color coordinates of (0.33, 0.30), according to the 1931 CIE chromaticity diagram, closely with the standard white light of (0.33, 0.33). The average luminescent lifetime of the white light SmCP is 0.35 ms, with τ1 = 0.19 ms (f 1 = 70.888), τ2 = 0.75 ms (f 2 = 29.112), and χ2 = 1.091, fitting well the biexponential function (Figure S7). And the quantum yield Φf is 8.27%.

As the most promising red emitting phosphors, the EuIII complexes have been fully investigated for the sharp emission at about 615 nm. For 6 (EuCP-1), under excitation at 395 nm, the emission spectra shows intense bands at 591, 614, and 691 nm, referring to the energy level diagrams proven by W. T. Carnall; those bands can be attributed to the 5D0 → 7FJ transitions with J = 1, 2, and 4, respectively, while the intensity of 5D0 → 7F3 transition at 649 nm is too weak to be observed (). In addition, the intensity of 5D0 → 7F2 transition is much stronger than that of 5D0 → 7F1 transition. The complex 7 (EuCP-2) displays a similar emission spectra with 6, the intense bands appearing at about 590, 613, 651, and 699 nm, which are attributed to the transitions of 5D0 → 7FJ with J = 1, 2, 3, and 4, respectively. And the CIE color coordinates are (0.58, 0.32) for 6 (EuCP-1), and (0.62, 0.34) for 7 (EuCP-2), indicating that they are good candidates as a red light emitter. As shown in Figure S9 and Figure S10, two EuCPs display similar decay curves, both fitted well with the double exponential function, with the average photoluminescent lifetimes being 0.34 ms (τ1 = 0.30 ms, f 1 = 70.750, τ2 = 0.42 ms, f 2 = 29.250, and χ2 = 1.286) for 6 (EuCP-1), and 0.48 ms (τ1 = 0.47 ms, f 1 = 95.243, τ2 = 0.60 ms, f 2 = 4.757, and χ2 = 1.121) for 7 (EuCP-2), respectively. Besides, the quantum yields Φf for 6 and 7 are 7.89%, and 3.33%, respectively.
